hints.content: Start by splitting the input sentence into individual words. You can use the `split()` method in Python, which will help you separate the words based on spaces.
Next, identify which words represent prices. A price word will start with a dollar sign '$' and be followed by digits. You can use string methods like `startswith()` and `isdigit()` to check this.
Remember that a valid price should have at least one digit after the '$'. So, check if the substring that follows '$' contains digits only.
Once you identify a price word, convert the price from a string to a float for calculations. You can do this by slicing the string to remove the '$' and then converting the remaining part to a float.
To apply the discount, calculate the new price using the formula: `new_price = original_price * (1 - discount / 100)`. Make sure to handle the discount correctly, especially when it is 100%.
After calculating the discounted price, format it to two decimal places. In Python, you can use formatted string literals or the `format()` function to ensure the output is in the correct format.
Replace the original price word in the list of words with the newly formatted price. This will ensure that your updated sentence contains the new prices.
Once all words have been processed, join the list of words back into a single string using the `join()` method. This will give you the final modified sentence.
Consider edge cases, such as when the discount is 0% (prices should remain the same) or 100% (all prices should become $0.00). Make sure your logic handles these correctly.
Finally, ensure that your function returns the modified sentence as required. Pay attention to the formatting, especially the two decimal places for all prices.

questionNotes: A word represents a price if it starts with '$' followed by digits.
All prices will contain at most 10 digits.
Output prices must be formatted to exactly two decimal places.
Discount can range from 0 to 100, affecting how prices are calculated.
